msDesc.head: Gregory the Great, Registrum epistolarum; etc.

msItem.rubric: Fol. 1r. Symbolum Fidei dictatum a beato Gregorio papa. Credo in unum deum omnipotentem
msItem.incipit: in nomine patris et filij et Spiritus sancti.
msItem.rubric: Registri Beati Gregory page urbis rome Liber Primus incipit... Valde necessarium esse perspeximus.
msItem.finalRubric: Epistole que pretennisse sunt de superioribus indictionibus. Gregorius sabiniano diacono constantinopolitano de causa maximi preuaricatoris
msItem.explicit: Fol. 163r. minime grauari permittat. Data die uicesima mensis ap<l> indictione secunda.
msItem.author: Gregory I
msItem.title: Registrum epistolarum

listBibl.bibl: Ed. D. Norberg, CCSL 140, 14oA (1982), not using this manuscript;
P. Ewald and L. M. Hartmann, MGH Epp. 1-2 (1887, 1898), not using this manuscript but noting it in ii, p. xxii;

msItem.note: Our text belongs to Hartmann's class Registrum Hadrianum cum epistulis praetemissis, common in Norman and English manuscripts from c.1100, and here with the letters in the order in Hartmann's edition. Those included in the Praetermissi are the standard omissions from the main text and are recorded by Hartmann, xxii.

msItem.rubric: Fol. 163r. Epistola felicis episcopi sicilie ad beatum papam Gregorium directa.
msItem.incipit: Domno [sic] beatissimo et honorabili. sancto patri Gregorio pape
msItem.explicit: Fol. 163v. Incolumen uos et deo placitum sancte pater patrum orantem pro nobis dominus custodiat in euum Amen.

msItem.rubric: Fol. 163v. Rescriptum sancti Gregorii ad eundem felicem episcopum.
msItem.explicit: Fol. 165r. seruare concedat. Amen. Data Kalendis nou.' indict. xiima.
msItem.title: Two pseudo-Isidorean pieces.

listBibl.bibl: Pr. as Gregory, Epp. XIV. 16-17, PL 77 .1320-8.

msItem.rubric: Fol. 165r. Sententia beati Gregorii pape de lapsu sacerdotum excerpta de decretis canonum.
msItem.incipit: Dilectissimo filio Secundino seruo dei incluso. Gregorius seruus seruorum dei. Tua sanctitatis a nobis requisiuit... sanguine suo redimere uenit.
Imagines quas a nobis tibi dirigendas
msItem.explicit: Fol. 166r. qui cunctum mundum est dignatus redimere. Jesus christus dominus. qui est in secula. Amen.
msItem.title: A pseudo-Isidorean version of Gregory.

listBibl.bibl: Ep. Ix. 147, ed. Hartmann (above, item 1), ii. 146/12-149/14.

supportDesc.foliation: Leaves are numbered in modern pencil.
supportDesc.collation: Collation: 1-208 216. Part of a series of quire signatures remains, d—m, q—t, written at the bottom centre of final leaves of quires. There are no catchwords.
supportDesc.condition: The leaves have some blemishes, some of which were repaired before use.

layoutDesc.layout:
Written in two columns, each
255-62 80 42 lines. Pricked in inner and outer margins and for verticals. Ruled in pencil and folded HSOS.

handDesc.handNote: Good protogothic bookhand by several scribes. Corrections are neatly written in the text. Punctuation is by low point, punctus elevatus, and punctus interrogativus.

decoDesc.decoNote: There are fine arabesque initials in vivid colours throughout comprising two ten-line initials on fol. 1r and others of a like size at the beginning of each book.
Smaller initials are two-line, usually plain but occasionally flourished: the principal colours are pale blue, crimson, red, green, and ochre.
There are rubrics throughout, and in major headings blue and green are used in addition to red. The form of S varies between the usual form and a reversed Z. Alexander and Temple, no. 61.

binding.p: Sewn on five bands between millboards covered with buckram and half-leather (s. xix), rebacked and with the heads of the leaves trimmed. On fol. 166v are holes and stains from the nails of a large chain-plate (position 1). There is a fore-edge tide. Repaired by Maltby July 1971 is on the front pastedown.

history.provenance:
Given to the College by Thomas Gascoigne, on whom see BRUO and W. A. Pronger, 'Thomas Gascoigne', EHR 53 (1938), 606-26,54 (1939), 20-37. This is probably the second supplement of the caution of Gascoigne and others of 13 April 1935 recorded on the back pastedown of Oxford, Lincoln College, MS lat. 105, 2o fo patimur. On fol. iiiv Gascoigne wrote Registrum sancti gregorii <pape erased> in .xiij. [sic] libris. datum collegio animarum fidelium per magistrum Thomam gascoigne. sacre pagine professorem eboracensis diocesis et dator libri vult quod concathenetur. in. libraria. communi. prefati collegii 1439o to the left of which is anno domini 1439 in another hand. In his Liber de veritatibus Gascoigne quotes Gregory's letters many times, presumably from this copy, in which there are his nota marks and other marginalia. Column numbers at the top of each column and the numbering of at least some of the letters are also his. At the top of fols. iiiv, ir, 92v, and v is the iesus maria inscription, with characteristic decorative punctuation, that he wrote in many of his manuscripts. Since the Liber de veritatibus was written 1434-57 (see Lincoln College, MS lat. 118, p. 14) Gascoigne must have parted with the manuscript before he had fully utilized it himself. It is possible that he obtained it from Abingdon Abbey; the fine initials are very similar to those in London, Lambeth Palace, MS 42, an Abingdon manuscript, and it is probably more than a coincidence that it too was in Gascoigne's hands, for he was resident in Oxford in the 1430s and 1440s, only a few miles from Abingdon. At the bottom of fol. 2r is ex libris style 1, Liber Collegij animarum omnium fidelium defunctorum de Oxon' Ex dono Magistri Thome Gascoigne sacre pagine professoris. 1439. Ker, All Souls, List II, no. 59, with 'Libri theologie cathenati'. No. 27 in James, Ecloga, and no. 1403 (2) in CMA.
All Souls library identifications, on which see Introduction, are, on the front pastedown, v.v.1.5 (deleted), MS 18, and L.R. 1.e.5 (pencil); fol. iiir, 5..11 in pencil; fol. iiiv bookplate no. 8. For an anecdote about the use of this manuscript by Francis Milles, fellow, in the 1560s, to settle a disputed reading of the text for Bp. John Jewel, see N. R. Ker in HUO iii. 447. In the second decade of the 17th century Thomas James, Bodley's Librarian, used the manuscript for his collation of the Fathers: see N. R. Ker, 'Thomas James's Collation of Gregory, Cyprian, and Ambrose', BLR 4 (1952-3), 16-30, 27 no. 24 for this manuscript.

recordHist.source: Andrew G. Watson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts of All Souls College Oxford (Oxford, 1997)

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact library@all-souls.ox.ac.uk.
